description: Back formation from Middle English confused (“frustrated, ruined”), from Anglo-Norman confus, from Latin confusus, past participle of confundō.

verbs.description: confuse (third-person singular simple present confuses, present participle confusing, simple past and past participle confused)

entries.meaning: (transitive) to puzzle, perplex, baffle, bewilder (somebody); to afflict by being complicated, contradictory, or otherwise difficult to understand
examples: It confused me when I went to the office and nobody was there, but then I realised it was Sunday.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To mix up, muddle up (one thing with another); to mistake (one thing for another).
examples: People who say "hola" to Italians are confusing Italian with Spanish.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To mix thoroughly; to confound; to disorder.
(transitive, dated) To make uneasy and ashamed; to embarrass.
